intro: Nothoscordum hirtellum subsp. hirtellum, commonly known as the hairy garlic, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, garlic-scented leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland or open habitats. Its leaves are hairy and broad, while its flowers are usually pink or purple, blooming in late spring to early summer. It is a perennial herb that is often found in shaded to partially shaded environments.
